title: Exploring the Use of Lipid-Monolayers Affinity Grids for CryoEM Structural Determination of Protein Complexes at a Multi-User Core Facility
content: Common obstacles in structural determination for single-particle cryo-electron microscopy (CryoEM) at the specimen level include protein denaturation at the air-water interface (AWI), preferred orientation, or low particle number [1]. The “ideal” cryo-grid contains areas of thin vitreous ice, densely populated with randomly oriented particles. A variety of solid supports, like amorphous carbon [2] and monolayer graphene oxide [3], have been used as non-selective solid supports that concentrate samples in the grid and partially protect from the AWI. More recently, use of affinity grids, consisting of a chemically modified TEM grid and designed to bind selectively to a target protein complex, have proven useful in determining the structure of samples not amendable to traditional TEM grid design. Among these affinity grids include chemically-modified carbon films [4] and graphene oxide [5], 2D crystals of streptavidin [6, 7] designed to bind biotin-conjugated samples, and lipid monolayers [8] containing modified lipids. Lipid monolayers have been used as a support film for growing 2D crystals and concentrating large protein complexes on the grid for structural determination using cryoEM [9, 10].
